Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 45135-001 
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
November 2011 
 
 
 
Asia Regional Integration Center, Phase IV  
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank

Head  I. Azis, Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI)

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In April 2005, the Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) was established to 
support the work of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) on regional cooperation and integration 
(RCI). In July 2006, ADB adopted an RCI strategy to support ADB's overarching goal of poverty 
reduction through regional collective actions.1 Consistent with this strategy, the OREI launched 
the Asia Regional Integration Center (ARIC) website in October 2006 as a one-stop, web-based 
knowledge and information portal on the progress of RCI initiatives in the region.2 This marked 
the first phase of an RCI-focused technical assistance (TA) project for ARIC. Further, in April 
2008,  ADB  adopted  Strategy  2020,  which  identified  regional  integration  as  one  of  three 
development agendas and RCI as one of its core specialization and operational areas.3  
 
2.  This TA aims to assist ADB’s RCI efforts by strengthening the ARIC website as a 
knowledge and information portal for RCI, thereby adding value to ADB's role as a knowledge 
institution. Building on the successes of previous TA projects, this TA will improve ARIC’s RCI 
databases and develop an indicator system to track the progress of regional integration and its 
effects in the region—contributing to economic growth and reducing economic uncertainty and 
financial volatility.4 It will also enhance ARIC’s role of keeping a close watch on, and providing 
up-to-date analyses of the changing global economic and financial environment—activities that 
have become more important in the wake of increasing global uncertainty and financial volatility. 
The design and monitoring framework for this TA is in Appendix 1.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Regional economic integration plays a vital role in improving productivity, accelerating 
economic  growth,  and  reducing  poverty.  It  is  thus  a  welcome  development  that  regional 
cooperation  and  integration  has  gained  momentum  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific.  In  2010, 
intraregional trade comprised 59.3% of the region’s trade flow, up from 54.9% in 2000. As of 
August 2011, 123 free trade agreements (FTAs) had been concluded, up from 45 in 2000. The 
region’s share of total foreign asset holdings also rose from 15% in 2001 to 27.9% in 2009. 
  
4.  A need remains, however, to promote greater awareness and understanding of the 
benefits of RCI. This can be achieved by providing reliable, timely, and accurate information on 
and analyses of various RCI initiatives in the region. Indeed, a prime opportunity for doing so is 
presented by the increased uncertainty and financial sector volatility that currently characterize 
the world economy. The growing tension in the eurozone also highlights one weakness of 
regional integration—contagion. These are key risk factors and important concerns for the 
region,  which  need  to  be  tracked;  their  regional  implications  need  to  be  considered,  and

precursor, the Asia Recovery Information Center, include: ADB. 1999. Technical Assistance for the Establishment 
of the Asia Recovery Information Center. Manila (TA 5848-REG); ADB. 2001. Technical Assistance for the Asia 
Recovery Information Center, Phase II. Manila (TA 5981-REG); ADB. 2003. Technical Assistance for the Asia 
Recovery Information Center, Phase III. Manila (TA 6138-REG); ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for the Asia 
Regional Integration Center. Manila (TA 6314-REG); ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance for the Asia Regional 
Integration Center, Phase II. Manila (TA 6459-REG); ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance for the Asia Regional 
Integration Center, Phase III. Manila (TA 7396-REG). 
5  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 22 September 2011.

2  
measures to mitigate their effects need to be identified. ARIC is in a unique position to assist in 
this function, having gained expertise in disseminating RCI knowledge and information widely, 
efficiently, and inexpensively. 
 
5.  Over  the  years,  TA  for  ARIC  has  contributed  to  the  increased  capacity  of  key 
stakeholders in the region to respond to various regional challenges. During the 1998/99 Asian 
financial crisis, the Asia Recovery Information Center provided reliable, timely, and accurate 
crisis-related information, which was vital for restoring confidence and facilitating economic 
recovery in the region. In March 2004, it was renamed the Asia Regional Information Center in 
recognition  of  its  key  role  in  disseminating  useful  knowledge  and  information  on  regional 
initiatives.  During  this  period,  the  Asia  Regional  Information  Center  continued  to  provide 
information on recovery efforts in Indonesia, the Republic of Korea, Malaysia, the Philippines, 
and Thailand, which was later extended to cover the People’s Republic of China, Singapore, 
and Viet Nam. In 2006, it was renamed the Asia Regional Integration Center and given a new 
mandate to serve as the knowledge and information portal on various RCI initiatives in the 
region. Its website was restructured to focus on four pillars: cross-border infrastructure and 
software, trade and investment, money and finance, and regional public goods.  
 
6.  The  ARIC  website  has  established  itself  as  a  reliable  and  leading  source  of  RCI 
knowledge  and  information.  It  provides  up-to-date  information  on  (i)  news,  opinions,  and 
editorials on a daily basis, as well as RCI-related studies; (ii) useful databases such as trade 
integration  and  FTAs;  investment,  macroeconomic,  monetary,  and  financial  indicators;  tax 
incentives; and climate change action plans and commitments, among others; (iii) calendars of 
economic data releases and RCI events; and (iv) early warning system indicators. It supports 
the publication of the Asia Economic Monitor (AEM), the RCI working papers, and other ADB 
flagship studies. ARIC also assists in the preparation of the economic prospects and policy 
issues  for  ASEAN+3  (confidential  notes),  which  are  ADB’s  contribution  to  the  biannual 
ASEAN+3 finance deputies’ meetings.6 
 
7.  ARIC’s information architecture, database systems, and state-of-the-art technology have 
been  used  as  a  benchmark  by  the  ASEAN  Statistics  Unit.  ARIC  also  assisted  in  the 
development of websites for Aid for Trade, the Global Reserve System, and the ADB Finance 
Community of Practice. The Secretariat for the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa 
consulted ARIC on its plan to establish a regional integration surveillance mechanism. In 2009, 
the ARIC website was included by the Center for Comparative Regional Integration Studies at 
the United Nations University in its best-practice analysis of online resources dealing with 
regional integration studies. The ARIC website’s FTA section is currently linked to the Asia and 
the Pacific trade and investment agreements database, which is maintained by the United 
Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific. The website attracts an 
average of 7,650 unique visitors and 50,100 downloads per month.    
 
8.  Following these achievements, this TA project will serve as the fourth phase of ARIC, 
which is timely given two important developments in the region.7  First, as a consequence of the 
                                                
6  ASEAN+3 countries include the 10 members of Association of Southeast Asian Nations plus the People's Republic 
of China, Japan, and the Republic of Korea. 
7  Overall assessments and ratings of previous ARIC-related TA projects were satisfactory. The Asia Economic 
Monitor, a publication under ARIC TA, has gained significant media coverage. For instance, (as of 29 July 2011), 
the July 2011 issue was covered by some 50 articles in international media, and was featured by regional and 
national newspapers. The British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) and Chinese Central Television (CCTV9) 
interviewed the Head of the OREI, Iwan Azis about the AEM as well. As of 31 August 2011, the December 2010 
issue has been downloaded about 605 times per month. The July 2010 issue also continues to generate interest

3
global financial crisis, growth needs to be rebalanced in favor of strengthening economic ties 
within Asia and the Pacific. This will not only give the region new growth drivers, but also make 
regional  economies  less  vulnerable  to  external  shocks.  Second,  due  to  heightened  global 
uncertainty  and  increasing financial  volatility,  regional  economic  cooperation  and  economic 
surveillance have gained significance.  
 
9.  ARIC phase IV aims to improve RCI monitoring by developing an RCI indicator system, 
which will track the progress of regional integration. The RCI indicator system will be developed 
in collaboration with ADB’s RCI Community of Practice and in consultation with the rest of ADB. 
It  aims  to  organize  and  combine  existing  regional  integration  indicators  so  as  to  gain  a 
multidimensional perspective of RCI trends. The aggregation of indicators will provide a holistic 
view of the progress of RCI. In addition, the RCI indicator system will include the perceptions of 
key stakeholders regarding the progress of and impediments to RCI in the region. It could also 
include other regional indicators from ADB’s results-based framework.  
 
10.  The results of the RCI indicator system will be reported in a new RCI publication—the 
RCI Monitor—which will discuss emerging trends and issues related to RCI. The RCI Monitor 
will also be presented in a regional seminar on RCI. It will complement other ADB seminars on 
RCI, which aim to enhance staff capability in this area. 
 
11.  The TA for ARIC also aims to integrate the center’s fragmented databases, so as to 
organize information for easy access by users. Not only will it feature the RCI indicator system 
(which  is  itself  a  way  of  organizing  and  summarizing  the  data  on  RCI),  it  will  strengthen 
information dissemination by developing country views within the website, improving the search 
engine, and conducting an annual survey of users to gather their views and suggestions on the 
ARIC website. 
 
12.  The new TA will also strengthen the relationships between ARIC and ADB regional 
departments  and  offices  through  closer  collaboration  in  the  production  of  key  knowledge 
products (the RCI indicator system, RCI Monitor, and RCI Digest) and improved content sharing 
and linkage between subregional and ARIC websites. These new products will serve as tangible 
contributions of the TA and raise the profile of ADB’s RCI work in the region. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The expected impact of the TA will be the implementation of existing RCI activities, 
development of new ones, and assisting in economic monitoring and greater policy dialogues in 
the region. The impact will be reflected in the number and scope of RCI initiatives, intraregional 
agreements, and other opportunities for cooperation (such as policy coordination). It will result in 
deeper  understanding  among  key  stakeholders  of  important  economic  issues  and,  when 
warranted, how RCI can help to maximize welfare gains or minimize losses in relation to those 
issues. The TA will also enhance the capabilities of stakeholders to track salient developments 
in global and regional economies. 
 
                                                                                                                                                       
and has been downloaded about 331 times per month. So far, the July 2011 AEM has been downloaded about 
2,273 times. Since April 2006, ARIC has assisted in the development and publication of about 86 working papers, 
which are available online on the ARIC website. In 2010, working paper downloads averaged 2,717 per month.

4  
14.  The expected outcome of the TA is that key stakeholders in the region will have greater 
access  to  economic  analysis  and  RCI-related  knowledge.8 In  turn,  this  will  enhance  their 
participation in RCI and economic monitoring and analysis activities. This outcome will be 
evident  through  greater  participation  by  key  stakeholders  in  regional  economic  integration 
seminars as well as high-quality discussions on RCI initiatives and regional economic issues. It 
is expected that the TA will also contribute to greater dissemination of RCI knowledge through 
increased website use—which is expected to go up by 10%—compared to the average use 
during October 2006–November 2011.9 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  The TA aims to develop the capacity of key stakeholders to promote greater regional 
integration by providing timely and relevant knowledge and information on RCI, facilitating 
regional  policy  dialogues  on  emerging  economic  issues,  and  supporting  research  and 
publication activities on RCI. In particular, the TA will have the following specific outputs: 
 
(i)  A  new  and  expanded  ARIC  website  and  updated  RCI  knowledge  and 
information in  the OREI  intranet. In particular, the quality of the website’s 
navigability, functionality, and dissemination capability will be improved. 
 
(ii)  Improvement  and  integration  of  various  RCI  databases,  including  the 
development of an indicator system for RCI, to track progress. 
 
(iii)  A  regional  seminar  to  present  the  RCI  indicator  system  and  the  RCI 
Monitor. Four other seminars to disseminate RCI knowledge will also be held. 
 
(iv)  Publication  of  three  issues  of  the  Asia  Economic  Monitor.  The 
macroeconomic and financial database of the report will also be improved. 
 
(v)  Publication of an RCI Monitor (1 issue), ADB working paper series on RCI 
(9 issues),  RCI  Digest  (9  issues),  monthly  update  (18  issues),  database 
reports (4 reports) and country profiles (10 profiles).  
 
(vi)  Increasing the profile of ADB’s RCI work using new forms of mass media. 
ARIC will also extend its network and expand its subscription list (or followers) 
through the use of new social media tools.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA will require an estimated $1,480,000 equivalent, to be financed on a grant basis 
by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF—other  sources).  The  detailed  cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB will be the executing agency of the TA. The OREI will implement the TA in close 
collaboration with other ADB departments and offices. The RCI Community of Practice will

provide advice and guidance. The TA will be implemented over 2 years, during December 
2011–November 2013.  
 
18.  It is estimated that the TA will require 9 international consultants with 51 person-months 
of consulting services, 15 national consultants with 256 person-months of consulting services, 
and 8 resource people with 1 person-month of participation. Individual consultants and resource 
people will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, 
as amended from time to time). The scope of work and outline terms of reference for the 
consultants are in Appendix 3. A team of OREI staff (1 international staff, 1 national officer, and 
1 operations assistant) will oversee the implementation of the TA. 
 
19.  One  international  consultant  will  act  as  the  lead  economist  to  supervise  ARIC’s 
operations. The other international consultants will include international economists, who will 
prepare special studies on RCI and assist in OREI seminars, and an economics and copyeditor, 
who will edit ARIC and OREI publications. National consultants will include one assistant lead 
economist, who will assist in the supervision of ARIC’s operations, and around eight economic 
analysts, who will maintain and update the content of the ARIC website, and assist in the 
preparation of OREI publications and seminars. Other national consultants include a website 
administrator,  multimedia  designer  and  developer,  system  and  database  developers,  a 
typesetter, and a project specialist to provide administrative support.  
 
20.  Purchases of equipment (computer hardware and software) and statistical databases will 
be undertaken in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time 
to time) and in coordination with ADB’s Office of Information Systems and Technology and 
Office of Administrative Services. After the TA is completed, all procured equipment will be 
disposed of in compliance with Administering Grant-Financed Technical Assistance Projects in 
the  Project  Administration  Instructions. 10  Disbursement  under  the  TA  will  be  made  in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). 
  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,480,000 on a grant basis 
for the Asia Regional Integration Center, Phase IV, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Lead Economist (18 person-months) 
 
1.  The  consultant  will  be  an  economist  with  expertise  in  trade,  macroeconomic,  and 
development issues in Asia and the Pacific, with at least 10 years of relevant work experience. 
Under the supervision of Asian Development Bank (ADB) staff, the lead economist will: 
(i)  manage the improvement, expansion, and daily operations of the Asia Regional 
Integration Center (ARIC) website; 
(ii)  evaluate  and  improve  the  content  and  operational  procedures  of  the  ARIC 
website, including the ARIC work plan; 
(iii)  develop and implement a monitoring framework for the ARIC website; 
(iv)  assist in the preparation of regular macroeconomic and financial reports; 
(v)  provide research inputs as may be requested by ADB staff; 
(vi)  manage the production of the ADB working paper series on regional cooperation 
and integration (RCI) and oversee preparations for the ADB seminar series on 
RCI; and 
(vii)  liaise with various ADB departments and offices. 
 
2.  Outputs  will  include  regular  reports  on  overall  activities  of  the  ARIC  team  and 
performance of or improvements in the ARIC website, written inputs and/or comments on logic 
and substance of various RCI knowledge products. 
 
2.  Economists (18 person-months in total) 
 
3.  The  consultants  will  be  economists  familiar  with  trade,  macroeconomics,  and 
development issues in Asia and the Pacific. Under the supervision of ADB staff, the consultants 
will: 
(i)  prepare special studies on agreed RCI-related topics and revise and finalize the 
studies based on comments from the Office of Regional Economic Integration 
(OREI) and other departments, and 
(ii)  draft and edit economic and other reports. 
 
4.  Outputs will include written reports and presentations on special studies regarding RCI 
issues. 
 
3.  Economics and Copyeditor (15 person-months) 
 
5.  The consultant should be familiar with economic and development issues in Asia and the 
Pacific,  and  have  strong  communication  skills.  Under  the  supervision  of  ADB  staff,  the 
consultant will:  
(i)  draft content for the ARIC website, the Asia Economic Monitor (AEM), ADB 
working  papers  on  regional  economic  integration,  management  statements, 
press releases, and technical documents; 
(ii)  examine economic arguments in documents to assess whether they are logical 
and are based on accepted economic theory and principles, and revise them if 
necessary; 
(iii)  examine and edit the tables and figures in documents to ensure data consistency; 
and

Appendix 3  11 
(iv)  ensure that documents adhere to ADB style and usage and conform to high 
publication standards. 
 
6.  Outputs will include edited content for the ARIC website, management statements, press 
releases,  OREI  publications  and  technical  documents,  and  written  notices  to  OREI  paper 
authors regarding the substance and logic of arguments and adherence to ADB style and usage. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
1.  Assistant Lead Economist (18 person-months) 
 
7.  The local consultant will have sufficient managerial capabilities to perform supervisory 
tasks,  extensive  knowledge  of  economic  and  policy  issues  in  the  region,  an  adequate 
background in database development and management; strong proficiency in data processing 
and  analysis,  familiarity  with  computer  applications  used  in  economic  analysis,  and 
commendable communication skills. Under the supervision of OREI staff and the ARIC lead 
economist, the local consultant will: 
(i)  perform the tasks of the team leader, in his/her absence; 
(ii)  assist in the management of the daily operations of the ARIC website;  
(iii)  help the team leader implement the ARIC work plan; 
(iv)  assist in the supervision of technical work done by ARIC team members; 
(v)  support the team leader in the preparation of management reports related to 
ARIC; 
(vi)  liaise with ADB departments and other stakeholders on ARIC-related matters; 
(vii)  provide research support in the preparation of the AEM by providing country 
notes and data assistance; and 
(viii)  execute data and research requests from OREI management and ADB staff. 
 
2.  Economic Analysts (144 person-months in total) 
 
8.  The consultants will help the ARIC lead economist to operate the ARIC website, develop 
and update indicators, provide data assistance, and prepare the AEM. The consultants, each 
engaged  for  18  person-months,  will  have  extensive  experience  in  economic,  social,  and 
financial data processing and analysis; be familiar with issues concerning regional cooperation 
and integration; have strong communication skills; and be proficient in using standard computer 
applications. Under the supervision of ADB staff and the ARIC team leader, the consultants will: 
(i)  maintain, develop, and contribute to the enhancement of the following sections of 
the website: 
(a)  RCI pillars (money and finance, trade and investment, infrastructure and 
software, regional public goods); 
(b)  RCI integration indicators and databases; 
(c)  economic and financial indicators; and 
(d)  other sections as may be required. 
(ii)  support the operations and development of the ARIC website; 
(iii)  assist in conceptualizing website design and front-end user tools and preparing 
requirements for content management systems;  
(iv)  prepare  RCI-related  knowledge  products  (including  RCI  Digest  and  country 
profiles on RCI indicators); 
(v)  assist in the preparation of the AEM and other OREI publications;  
(vi)  prepare macroeconomic and financial monitoring reports (daily and weekly);

Appendix 3  13 
(v)  provide support for site uploads, and editing for all ARIC online materials and 
publications; 
(vi)  conceptualize and implement designs for ARIC and OREI promotional materials; 
(vii)  provide layout services for various ARIC documents and OREI publications; 
(viii)  coordinate  with  relevant  departments  to  ensure  graphic  design  work  on  the 
website is consistent with ADB design guidelines; 
(ix)  provide photography support and in-house post-production video editing, transfer 
to  media  to  CD/DVD,  prepare  cover  designs,  and  respond  to  reproduction 
requests; and 
(x)  assist in various ARIC local events. 
 
5.  System and Database Developer (18 person-months) 
 
11.  The consultant will help the ARIC lead economist to expand, improve, and operate the 
ARIC website. The consultant will work at the ADB headquarters. Under the supervision of ADB 
staff and the ARIC lead economist, the consultant will: 
(i)  improve  the  content  management  system  for  the  ARIC  databases,  which 
includes generating new html and excel outputs needed for reports and website 
uploads, and adding new functions to the front-end interface of the database; 
(ii)  maintain  and  upgrade  the  content  management  system  for  all  the  ARIC 
databases,  which  includes  adding  new  functions  to  facilitate  user-defined 
interface or inputs of various types of data, and creating new outputs for website 
uploads and research; 
(iii)  enhance,  optimize,  and  integrate  the  databases  and  content  management 
systems for the ARIC databases as may be determined by the team; 
(iv)  assist in the supervision of database-related collaboration projects with other 
ADB departments and external stakeholders, which includes scoping of data 
requirements, and assisting in the conceptualization of the IT plan and framework; 
(v)  conceptualize,  design,  and  implement  other  database-related  system 
requirements for the website, particularly for new content as may be determined 
by the ARIC team; 
(vi)  design and implement front-end web tools to enhance website functionality and 
presentation; 
(vii)  prepare  manuals  and  technical  documentation  for  the  ARIC  databases  and 
content management systems; 
(viii)  conduct and oversee usability testing for the ARIC website; and 
(ix)  provide other IT support as may be requested by the lead economist and/or ADB 
staff. 
 
6.  Typesetter (4 person-months) 
 
12.  The consultant will lay out the reports (at least 3 issues of the AEM) for publication and 
convert the files into the required format for print and/or online publication. In consultation with 
and under the guidance of ADB staff, the consultant will:  
(i)  design the AEM cover, layout text, tables, and charts for the AEM in Adobe 
Indesign CS2 and Adobe Illustrator CS2, and incorporate revisions to the text, 
tables, and charts; and 
(ii)  convert the Adobe files into PDF files for online and print publication. 
 
7.  Project Specialist (18 person-months)
